entry.content:
Welcome to Hexo! This is your very first post. Check documentation for more info. If you get any problems when using Hexo, you can find the answer in troubleshooting or you can ask me on GitHub.

entry.title: The Kingdom of the Lion
entry.content:
The Kingdom of the Lion

THE BEASTS of the field and forest had a Lion as their king. He was neither wrathful, cruel, nor tyrannical, but just and gentle as a king could be. During his reign he made a royal proclamation for a general assembly of all the birds and beasts, and drew up conditions for a universal league, in which the Wolf and the Lamb, the Panther and the Kid, the Tiger and the Stag, the Dog and the Hare, should live together in perfect peace and amity. The Hare said, â€œOh, how I have longed to see this day, in which the weak shall take their place with impunity by the side of the strong.â€ And after the Hare said this, he ran for his life.

entry.title: Joe's first car
entry.content:
Lesson 2ï¼šJoeâ€™s first car

Joeâ€™s first car
Joe is 18 years old.
Joe works at McDonaldâ€™s.
Joe saves all his money.
Joe has $2500.00 in the bank.
He wants to buy a sports car.
Joe starts to look for a new car.
Joe looks in the newspaper.
Joe looks at magazines.
Joe finds a car he likes.
Joe goes to see the car with his dad.
He really likes it.
Joe doesnâ€™t have enough money.
Joeâ€™s dad tells him to keep saving his money.
Joe wants this car a lot.
Joe asks his dad help him.
Joe and his dad make a deal.
Joeâ€™s dad will lend him the money.
Joe must work hard.
He must pay the money back to his dad.
Joe is very happy.
Joe owns his first car.

entry.title: The Emperors New Clothes
entry.content:
The Emperors New Clothes

Many years ago, there was an Emperor, who was so excessively fond of new clothes, that he spent all his money in dress. He did not trouble himself in the least about his soldiers; nor did he care to go either to the theatre or the chase, except for the opportunities then afforded him for displaying his new clothes. He had a different suit for each hour of the day; and as of any other king or emperor, one is accustomed to say, â€œhe is sitting in council,â€ it was always said of him, â€œThe Emperor is sitting in his wardrobe.â€

Time passed merrily in the large town which was his capital; strangers arrived every day at the court. One day, two rogues, calling themselves weavers, made their appearance. They gave out that they knew how to weave stuffs of the most beautiful colors and elaborate patterns, the clothes manufactured from which should have the wonderful property of remaining invisible to everyone who was unfit for the office he held, or who was extraordinarily simple in character.

â€œThese must, indeed, be splendid clothes!â€ thought the Emperor. â€œHad I such a suit, I might at once find out what men in my realms are unfit for their office, and also be able to distinguish the wise from the foolish! This stuff must be woven for me immediately.â€ And he caused large sums of money to be given to both the weavers in order that they might begin their work directly.

So the two pretended weavers set up two looms, and affected to work very busily, though in reality they did nothing at all. They asked for the most delicate silk and the purest gold thread; put both into their own knapsacks; and then continued their pretended work at the empty looms until late at night.

â€œI should like to know how the weavers are getting on with my cloth,â€ said the Emperor to himself, after some little time had elapsed; he was, however, rather embarrassed, when he remembered that a simpleton, or one unfit for his office, would be unable to see the manufacture. To be sure, he thought he had nothing to risk in his own person; but yet, he would prefer sending somebody else, to bring him intelligence about the weavers, and their work, before he troubled himself in the affair. All the people throughout the city had heard of the wonderful property the cloth was to possess; and all were anxious to learn how wise, or how ignorant, their neighbors might prove to be.

â€œI will send my faithful old minister to the weavers,â€ said the Emperor at last, after some deliberation, â€œhe will be best able to see how the cloth looks; for he is a man of sense, and no one can be more suitable for his office than be is.â€

So the faithful old minister went into the hall, where the knaves were working with all their might, at their empty looms.

â€œWhat can be the meaning of this?â€ thought the old man, opening his eyes very wide.

â€œI cannot discover the least bit of thread on the looms.â€ However, he did not express his thoughts aloud.

The impostors requested him very courteously to be so good as to come nearer their looms; and then asked him whether the design pleased him, and whether the colors were not very beautiful; at the same time pointing to the empty frames.

The poor old minister looked and looked, he could not discover anything on the looms, for a very good reason, viz: there was nothing there.

â€œWhat!â€ thought he again. â€œIs it possible that I am a simpleton? I have never thought so myself; and no one must know it now if I am so. Can it be, that I am unfit for my office? No, that must not be said either. I will never confess that I could not see the stuff.â€

â€œWell, Sir Minister!â€ said one of the knaves, still pretending to work. â€œYou do not say whether the stuff pleases you.â€

â€œOh, it is excellent!â€ replied the old minister, looking at the loom through his spectacles. â€œThis pattern, and the colors, yes, I will tell the Emperor without delay, how very beautiful I think them.â€

â€œWe shall be much obliged to you,â€ said the impostors, and then they named the different colors and described the pattern of the pretended stuff. The old minister listened attentively to their words, in order that he might repeat them to the Emperor; and then the knaves asked for more silk and gold, saying that it was necessary to complete what they had begun. However, they put all that was given them into their knapsacks; and continued to work with as much apparent diligence as before at their empty looms.

The Emperor now sent another officer of his court to see how the men were getting on, and to ascertain whether the cloth would soon be ready. It was just the same with this gentleman as with the minister; he surveyed the looms on all sides, but could see nothing at all but the empty frames.

â€œDoes not the stuff appear as beautiful to you, as it did to my lord the minister?â€ asked the impostors of the Emperorâ€™s second ambassador; at the same time making the same gestures as before, and talking of the design and colors which were not there.

â€œI certainly am not stupid!â€ thought the messenger. â€œIt must be, that I am not fit for my good, profitable office! That is very odd; however, no one shall know anything about it.â€ And accordingly he praised the stuff he could not see, and declared that he was delighted with both colors and patterns. â€œIndeed, please your Imperial Majesty,â€ said he to his sovereign when he returned, â€œthe cloth which the weavers are preparing is extraordinarily magnificent.â€

The whole city was talking of the splendid cloth which the Emperor had ordered to be woven at his own expense.

And now the Emperor himself wished to see the costly manufacture, while it was still in the loom. Accompanied by a select number of officers of the court, among whom were the two honest men who had already admired the cloth, he went to the crafty impostors, who, as soon as they were aware of the Emperorâ€™s approach, went on working more diligently than ever; although they still did not pass a single thread through the looms.

â€œIs not the work absolutely magnificent?â€ said the two officers of the crown, already mentioned. â€œIf your Majesty will only be pleased to look at it! What a splendid design! What glorious colors!â€ and at the same time they pointed to the empty frames; for they imagined that everyone else could see this exquisite piece of workmanship.

â€œHow is this?â€ said the Emperor to himself. â€œI can see nothing! This is indeed a terrible affair! Am I a simpleton, or am I unfit to be an Emperor? That would be the worst thing that could happen.

â€œOh! the cloth is charming,â€ said he, aloud. â€œIt has my complete approbation.â€

And he smiled most graciously, and looked closely at the empty looms; for on no account would he say that he could not see what two of the officers of his court had praised so much. All his retinue now strained their eyes, hoping to discover something on the looms, but they could see no more than the others; nevertheless, they all exclaimed, â€œOh, how beautiful!â€ and advised his majesty to have some new clothes made from this splendid material, for the approaching procession. â€œMagnificent! Charming! Excellent!â€ resounded on all sides; and everyone was uncommonly gay. The Emperor shared in the general satisfaction; and presented the impostors with the riband of an order of knighthood, to be worn in their button-holes, and the title of â€œGentlemen Weavers.â€

The rogues sat up the whole of the night before the day on which the procession was to take place, and had sixteen lights burning, so that everyone might see how anxious they were to finish the Emperorâ€™s new suit. They pretended to roll the cloth off the looms; cut the air with their scissors; and sewed with needles without any thread in them. â€œSee!â€ cried they, at last. â€œThe Emperorâ€™s new clothes are ready!â€

And now the Emperor, with all the grandees of his court, came to the weavers; and the rogues raised their arms, as if in the act of holding something up, saying, â€œHere are your Majestyâ€™s trousers! Here is the scarf! Here is the mantle! The whole suit is as light as a cobweb; one might fancy one has nothing at all on, when dressed in it; that, however, is the great virtue of this delicate cloth.â€

â€œYes indeed!â€ said all the courtiers, although not one of them could see anything of this exquisite manufacture.

â€œIf your Imperial Majesty will be graciously pleased to take off your clothes, we will fit on the new suit, in front of the looking glass.â€

The Emperor was accordingly undressed, and the rogues pretended to array him in his new suit; the Emperor turning round, from side to side, before the looking glass.

â€œHow splendid his Majesty looks in his new clothes, and how well they fit!â€ everyone cried out. â€œWhat a design! What colors! These are indeed royal robes!â€

â€œThe canopy which is to be borne over your Majesty, in the procession, is waiting,â€ announced the chief master of the ceremonies.

â€œI am quite ready,â€ answered the Emperor. â€œDo my new clothes fit well?â€ asked he, turning himself round again before the looking glass, in order that he might appear to be examining his handsome suit.

The lords of the bedchamber, who were to carry his Majestyâ€™s train felt about on the ground, as if they were lifting up the ends of the mantle; and pretended to be carrying something; for they would by no means betray anything like simplicity, or unfitness for their office.

So now the Emperor walked under his high canopy in the midst of the procession, through the streets of his capital; and all the people standing by, and those at the windows, cried out, â€œOh! How beautiful are our Emperorâ€™s new clothes! What a magnificent train there is to the mantle; and how gracefully the scarf hangs!â€ in short, no one would allow that he could not see these much-admired clothes; because, in doing so, he would have declared himself either a simpleton or unfit for his office. Certainly, none of the Emperorâ€™s various suits, had ever made so great an impression, as these invisible ones.

â€œBut the Emperor has nothing at all on!â€ said a little child.

â€œListen to the voice of innocence!â€ exclaimed his father; and what the child had said was whispered from one to another.

â€œBut he has nothing at all on!â€ at last cried out all the people.

The Emperor was vexed, for he knew that the people were right; but he thought the procession must go on now! And the lords of the bedchamber took greater pains than ever, to appear holding up a train, although, in reality, there was no train to hold.

entry.title: my first pet
entry.content:
Lesson 1ï¼šMy First Pet

My first pet
My name is sarah.
I am 14 years old.
I have a pet cat.
My catâ€™s name is Milo.
My cat is black and white.
Miloâ€™s paws are white.
Miloâ€™s body is black.
She is very cute.
Miloâ€™s fur is very soft.
Milo was a very small kitten.
Milo is a very big cat.
Milo cannot have kittens.
She is fixed.
Milo likes to eat.
Milo likes to play outside.
Milo likes to hunt for birds.
Milo likes to hunt for mice.
She likes her ears scratched.
Milo likes to sit in my lap.
Milo likes to sleep on my bed.
Milo is a good pet.

Too late

Education

Review

Indifference

One who has journeyed upon the sea seldom reflects on those left ashore. One who remains on land rarely speaks of the trials at sea.

A newcomer should refrain from inquiring about bygone days.

Who first uttered these words?

And who, indeed, can accomplish the truly unforeseen?

æˆ‘çˆ¶äº²ä¹Ÿå¾ˆæ‡‚æ„Ÿæ©ã€‚å¤§å“¥çš„å„¿å­å’ŒäºŒå“¥çš„å„¿å­ä¸Šå¤§å­¦åï¼Œæˆ‘çˆ¶äº²éƒ½åˆ†åˆ«ç»™äºˆäº†ä»–ä»¬ä¸¤ä¸ªæœ€å¤§é™åº¦çš„èµ„åŠ©ã€‚70å¹´ä»£æˆ‘çˆ¶äº²è¿˜æƒ³æ–¹è®¾æ³•æ‰¾åˆ°äº†ä»–å§å§çš„å¥³å„¿ï¼Œä¹Ÿå¼€å§‹æ—¶å¸¸åœ¨ç»æµä¸Šå¸®åŠ©å¥¹ã€‚

æˆ‘çˆ¶äº²ç»™æˆ‘è¯´ï¼Œå®¶é‡Œç©·çš„è¯ï¼Œå®¶é‡Œçš„äººçš„æ•™å…»æˆ–è€…è§‰æ‚Ÿå°±ä¸ä¼šå¤ªé«˜ã€‚çœ‹æ¥æ˜¯æœ‰é“ç†çš„ã€‚

Reasonâ€“remembering my father

Remember, when we were children, my mother angrily complained to us about my fatherâ€™s family. During a hard time, my fatherâ€™s brothers sold my fatherâ€™s house in the village and did not inform my father, etc. So we thought that my fatherâ€™s family was not kind at that time, and we thought my fatherâ€™s brothers were bad. When we were teenagers, we did not meet my fatherâ€™s brothers. Or we did not want to see them at all. We should call them uncle. And did not want to see their children. But my father did not regard these matters.

After my father spoke to me about his family more and more, I could understand his family and deeply see the reason. My fatherâ€™s family was a little rich, so all of the family were happy together because there were no problems with finances. My grandpa was a normal boss who managed a very small paper factory, he had hard made it run. My fatherâ€™s big brother was a teacher, he was a village manager, My fatherâ€™s second brother was also a village manager. After my fatherâ€™s sister was married, she made shoes for four men of my fatherâ€™s family in a short time during she went back home. Unfortunately, she died when she was a little young. But my father respected her very well.

My father should have gratituded his big brother most, but my mother thought that his big brother was not the kindliest. At that time, my grandpa hoped my father continue the family career, so education did not need more. But his big brother did not agree with Grandpa and persisted that my father ought to study. So my fatherâ€™s big brother took my father to the school for learning where his big brother worked as a teacher. Later my father went to a good advanced school, and then my father went to a good university. From this point my fatherâ€™s big brother was certainly a well-deserved teacher, he watched far more than others around him. The result of my father was from his big brother, who had a key role in my fatherâ€™s life after.

My father is very grateful to those who helped him. He supported his big brotherâ€™s son and his second brotherâ€™s son while they studied at a university. After many years, my father spent more time and difficulty finding his sisterâ€™s daughter and gave her help with money often.

My father told me that those would not have good behavior and good consciousness because their family was poor. So it makes sense.

entry.title: ä¸€ä¸ªçœŸå®çš„æ•…äº‹
entry.content:
A True Story

This is a true story that happened close to me. It shows how illness can bring tremendous changes to a family.
The mother in this family was a kind and graceful woman. Before retiring, she held a good job. Her son secured a promising position after completing his studies abroad, and her husband had a respectable career. Together, they lived a happy and peaceful life.

One day, the mother began to feel unwell, suffering from frequent headaches. She was taken to the hospital for a check-up, which revealed that her blood pressure was abnormally high. The doctor advised her to go to a larger hospital for further tests, but she didnâ€™t take it seriously and chose not to follow up.
A few days later, her condition worsened. Her blood pressure rose sharply, and her family rushed her to the hospital. She had suffered a brain hemorrhage and was taken into emergency surgery. Although the operation was successful, she didnâ€™t regain consciousness immediately.
Two months later, she finally woke upâ€”but she was no longer the same. The illness had left her severely disabled, and since then, she has required professional care day and night.
Her husband visited her in the hospital every single day, staying by her side through the long recovery. Her son, due to various reasons, had to quit his job. Eventually, he started working as a real estate salesman. By then, he was thirty-four years old and still unmarried.
A once joyful and promising family was forever changed by the motherâ€™s illness.
This story reminds us that health is fragile, and life can change in an instant. We should cherish every moment of peace and health, and never take them for granted. Pay attention to the warning signs, take care of our loved ones, and live each day with gratitude.ã€

entry.title: ä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆæ´»åœ¨è¿™ä¸ªä¸–ç•Œ
entry.content:
what do they live for

Many people spend their whole lives bowing and compromising â€” trying to be worthy of everyone but themselves. I truly believe this isnâ€™t the life most of us long for.

Live fully in the present. Savor each day, each fleeting moment. Donâ€™t dwell on the past you cannot change, nor chase after a future you cannot control. Let life unfold â€” what comes will come, and what goes is meant to go.

Most people, before reaching middle age, work tirelessly for their children and parents, enduring the scorn and pressure from their superiors. Then, after middle age, they spend 90% of their remaining time merely in exchange for the final 10% of life â€” called retirement.

There are three stages of development:
First, people donâ€™t trust you.

entry.title: å…³æ³¨å¥åº·
entry.content:
Focus on health

Health was never seen as the most important thingâ€”until illness showed up in my own body.
For example, I used to ignore dental health when I was young. Now, at sixty-five, I realize I should have started protecting my teeth many years ago. Back then, I didnâ€™t take it seriously and thought all those warnings were just tedious advice.
We really should follow the laws of science and listen to othersâ€™ suggestions.
The same goes for many other things in life.

entry.title: å²æœˆé™å¥½
entry.content:
Good Times

Many people believe that good times simply mean that misfortunes are happening elsewhereâ€”to others, not to themselves.It is peace by omission, a quiet bought with distance and chance. As long as suffering stays out of sight, they call the world kind.When storms rage far away, they close their windows and claim itâ€™s a sunny day.They mistake absence for immunity, believing that fortune is their birthright.But fate has no favorites. One day, what they chose to ignore may arrive uninvited.

entry.title: è°è¨€ä¸çœŸç†
entry.content:
Lies And Truth

Lies are the demand of society.
They are like noise-canceling earmuffs, silencing the voice of truth.
A cloth over the eyes, blinding the way forward.
A dream-making machine, feeding illusions to the restless crowd.
To believe a lie requires no thought.
But to believe the truth demands rare insight and deep ingenuity.
In such a world, truth remains forever weaker than lies.

The sheep feared wolves all their lives. But in the end, they were eaten by the shepherd. The shepherd said, â€œIf I hadnâ€™t protected you, the wolves would have eaten you long ago â€” so you should be grateful to me.â€

åŒ»ç”Ÿè€å¿ƒåœ°è§£é‡Šè¯´ï¼šâ€œå¦‚æœä¸åšæ‰‹æœ¯ï¼Œä½ å¯èƒ½ä¼šå¤±æ˜ã€‚â€è¿™å¯¹è€å¤«å¦»æ²‰é»˜äº†ã€‚ä»–ä»¬çœ‹ä¸Šå»æ— åŠ©è€Œä¸å®‰ï¼Œå¥½åƒä¸çŸ¥é“è¯¥æ€ä¹ˆåŠæ‰å¥½ã€‚åŒ»ç”Ÿåˆä¸€æ¬¡é‡ç”³äº†è‡ªå·±çš„å»ºè®®ï¼Œä½†å¤«å¦»ä¿©è¯´ä»–ä»¬éœ€è¦æ—¶é—´å¥½å¥½å•†é‡ä¸€ä¸‹ã€‚

æˆ‘çœ‹ç€ä»–ä»¬æ…¢æ…¢èµ°è¿œï¼Œå¿ƒé‡Œæ„Ÿåˆ°ä¸€é˜µé…¸æ¥šã€‚æˆ‘èƒ½æ„Ÿå—åˆ°ä»–ä»¬çš„ææƒ§ä¸ä¸ç¡®å®šï¼Œä¹Ÿè®¸æ˜¯ç¼ºä¹å‹‡æ°”ï¼Œä¹Ÿè®¸æ˜¯ç¼ºä¹ç»æµèƒ½åŠ›ã€‚ä½†æ— è®ºå“ªç§åŸå› ï¼Œéƒ½è®©äººéš¾è¿‡ã€‚

åæ¥ï¼Œæˆ‘æŠŠè¿™ä»¶äº‹è®²ç»™æœ‹å‹å¬ã€‚æœ‰ä¸ªæœ‹å‹è¯´ï¼šâ€œè¿™å¾ˆæ­£å¸¸ã€‚â€ä¹Ÿè®¸ç¡®å®æ˜¯å§ã€‚æœ‹å‹çš„è¯åæ˜ äº†ç¤¾ä¼šçš„ç°å®ï¼Œä½†å¬èµ·æ¥å´æœ‰äº›å†·æ¼ ã€‚è€Œæˆ‘ï¼Œåªæ˜¯æƒ³è¡¨è¾¾ä¸€ç§å–„æ„â€”â€”ä¸€ç§æ„¿æ„ä¼¸å‡ºæ´æ‰‹çš„å¿ƒï¼Œä¸€ç§å¸Œæœ›è¿™ä¸ªä¸–ç•Œèƒ½å¤šä¸€ç‚¹æ¸©æƒ…çš„æ€åº¦ã€‚

Need to concern

Yesterday, I saw an elderly couple speaking with a doctor about the wifeâ€™s upcoming eye surgery.The husband was asking for detailed information, while the wife looked hesitant, as if she didnâ€™t really want to go through with it.

The doctor explained patiently, â€œIf you donâ€™t have the surgery, you may lose your eyesight.â€The couple fell silent. They looked helpless and unsure, like they didnâ€™t know what to do.The doctor repeated his advice, but the couple said they needed time to discuss it.

As I watched them walk away slowly, I could feel their fear and uncertainty. I sensed that they lacked the courageâ€”or perhaps the meansâ€”to go through with it. It made me feel deeply sad.

Later, I told my friends about what I had seen. One of them said, â€œThatâ€™s normal.â€Yes, maybe it is.My friendâ€™s words reflect the reality of society, but they feel a bit cold.I just wanted to express a kind intentionâ€”to help, and to stand for a more caring attitude in the world we live in.

entry.title: é¢åŒ…ä¸é¦’å¤´
entry.content:
Bread and Steamed Buns

I have made bread for many years, and sometimes I made steamed buns, so I thought that there were big differences between them. Perhaps it is even a cultural difference.

Cooking method: Steamed buns are steamed.
Bread is baked.

Tools and tradition: kitchens where the steamed buns were made used steamers.
Kitchens where the bread was made had ovens.

Texture preference: people who eat the steamed buns like soft, fluffy textures.
People who eat bread prefer crispy or chewy bread.

Eating habits: Steamed buns are shared in meals.
Bread is often eaten alone or in sandwiches.

Precision: Making bread needs careful control of weight, temperature, and time.
Steamed buns are simpler to make and more flexible.

This shows the Culture of the place where the bread was made values precision, while the culture of the place where the steamed buns were made values practicality.
